The courtyard/garden is SO peaceful and is a great place to sit and relax. Breakfast was great, too, and the people working there were very helpful. Do be warned about the winding steps situation though- if you are carrying big suitcases or have trouble walking up and down stairs, think twice. Definitely not handicap-accessible! But as long as you don't mind some stairs, definitely book here!

Reviews.Title: “LOVED this hotel, can't wait to go back to Istanbul!”
Reviews.Author: ngchang
Reviews.Content: I agree with the other reviewers on here that Empress Zoe is an oasis - the beautfiul gardens, the dark wood rooms with plenty of privacy. We booked the Garden Suite and loved the separated bedroom with our 2 teens on twin beds in the living room, separated by a very modern bath. The location was great, there is plenty to do within walking distance, or you can walk to the tram. The service at this hotel was amazing - and do yourself a favor and take their restaurant recommendations! No pool, but free wireless internet in the garden where you take your breakfast. Also, we were happy with our arranged taxi to and from the airport with them (25 Euro each way) We even took the commuter ferry over to the Asia side of the city and it was worth every bit of the $1 US to see the beautiful river up close and the Topaki palace and Blue Mosque (which we had just visited) from the river.

Reviews.Title: “Our first visit to Istanbul, certainly not the last.”
Reviews.Author: riverside65
Reviews.Content: Our recent stay in Istanbul, June 1st -6th, was made such a pleasure , by being guests in the friendly and well run Hotel Empress Zoe. Its position in the Sultanahmet area of the city,meant only a short walk up to the Blue Mosque and many other points of interest,while having the convenience of many good resturants and coffee shops close by.The staff always on hand in the attractive reception area, could not have been more helpful or informative. Our terrace suite was very comfortable and kept immaculately clean. It overlooked the peaceful and leafy courtyard garden,a welcome retreat from the heat and bustle of the city. this was where we took our breakfast, after helping ourselves from the excellent choices, which seemed to please every nationality. The Hotel had much character and was on many levels including spiral stairs,and a tremendous view from the little roof terraces. This required a certain degree of agility, but we`re in our seventies and managed it easily.We shall certainly go back

Reviews.Title: “Unique and lovely traditionally styled hotel in great location”
Reviews.Author: comiles
Reviews.Content: My friend and I stayed in a 'petit suite' which provided extra privacy as it has two rooms and a bathroom. We arrived a three days before check-in as were were travelling by train later in that day to Capadoccia and the hotel kindly agreed to hold our main baggage until we returned and let us use shower facilities which was greatly apprecieted and not expected! This helpfuless extended throughout our actual stay at this lovely hotel. The location is perfect for all the sightseeing you need to do in the area! The roof terrace is lovely and has great views. Can be a bit breezy but worth it for a relaxing cold beer or wine! There are sun loungers on the terrace too which if you wanted a relaxing afternoon away from the hustle and bustle of vibrant Istanbul! The breakfast is a fresh Turkish breakfast which was perfect, especially if taken in the shady garden courtyard. The hotel itself is in a relatively quiet and pleasant location so noise was not an issue. The hotel doesnt have a restaurant but there are plenty of eateries in the surrounding streets serving the usual Turkish cuisine! This area is probably a little more expensive for eating/drinking etc. than other areas (eg. Taksim) as it is in the heart of the historical old quarter of Istanbul. If arriving via taxi from Taksim Square the fare during regular hours should be around TLire 15.00. We were charged Tlire 30.00 on initial arrival so beware!

Reviews.Title: “A most charming hotel”
Reviews.Author: MegnSkipper
Reviews.Content: This hotel was recommended by a friend as her favorite in Istanbul. It's now mine! Thankfully, the staff takes your luggage up the narrow spiral staircase. The garden is lovely, and a wonderful place to enjoy breakfast in the warmer months. I stayed two nights and had the good fortune to experience two different rooms: the Garden Suite and Family Suite. Both were very spacious and comfortable. The Garden Suite has a balcony and view of the charming garden; the Family Suite includes a crib for a baby. The late afternoon/evening staff is very nice and lowkey (I didn't see much of the daytime staff because I was out), unlike the shop and restaurant owners on the street who are constantly trying to lure you in. The hotel is located very close to the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque, and the street it's on is filled with restaurants. Be sure to try Balik Sabahattin for fish and mezes -- a hotel recommendation. Also, read through the list of restaurants recommended by the hotel (the laminated list is in the room) -- they all sound great. The hotel is intimate, charming and conveniently located; a wonderful choice for your visit to Istanbul. I returned to Istanbul later during my trip and stayed at Hotel Arcadia, located a couple of streets above the Blue Mosque. That hotel has great views of the sites, but is larger and impersonal, and the staff was very aloof. I felt that they recommended restaurants and services from which they receive commission.

Reviews.Title: “perfect base for istanbul”
Reviews.Author: exheel_9
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a two floor suite. the top floor had two small beds and a kitchen and two balconies (one overlooking the bosporous and one looking out at the hagia sophia and the blue mosque). the room was pretty basic but comfortable and could sleep 5 (we had 4 and had an extra sofa bed left). Pro's were the hotel felt very exotic but comfortable and roomy at the same time, the location was absolutely perfect (it is literally across the street from the 4 seasons and 3 blocks from the hagia sophia), it was very reasonably priced, the staff was very helpful, and the garden used for breakfast and sitting around in the afternoon was just great (note that there is a 1.5 page picture spread of the garden in an article on istanbul carpet shopping in a very recent national geographic traveller magazine) - hard to express how unique that the garden was but it comes across in that picture Only real con was while the breakfast setting was perfect, the breakfast buffet wasn't all that great as to what they had. but the setting for breakfast made up for it. the other thing to note is that to get into the hotel thru the lobby, you have to go up thru a narrow metal spiral staircase in the center of the lobby which isnt the easiest thing to navigate thru. another caveat was that its in range of around 3 or 4 minarets and the call to prayer is very loud there as a result and it goes off at 5am. woke us up first day but got used to it overall a great place. hard to imagine a better base for istanbul

Reviews.Title: “Great location, cozy.”
Reviews.Author: Ronim_lad
Reviews.Content: After reading all the reviews and being drawn to the name of the place I booked Empress Zoe for 4 nights stay with a friend. Great location, right next to Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sophia. Would recommend this to anyone. There is a very friendly atmosphere and it is decorated beautifully. The cats were entertaining too. Only problem being the weakness of the British pound at the moment against the hotel prices which are quoted in Euros.

Reviews.Title: “A cozy hotel with friendly staff”
Reviews.Author: MayaNice
Reviews.Content: Stayed in the Empress Zoe just before the easter weekend and thoroughly enjoyed our stay. It's a charming hotel with a roof top terrace and view to the Blue Mosque, and a courtyard garden nestled between the buildings and an abandoned Hamam. The nearby mosque woke us up regularly before 6am, but it only added to the atmosphere of being in Istanbul. The staff were very polite, all spoke good english, and helpful when asked for guidance, taxis etc. We stayed in one of the family rooms (bedroom and sitting room with 2 sofa/beds). It was simple but clean. The "private courtyard" was just the the space between door and the back gate, so not of great attraction but we were at ground level with the garden. We found the price of the room high but it was the only option left when we booked in February. The only drawback would be for elderly or handicapped persons as the passage to all rooms is via a spiral staircase from the reception and the hotel has no lift as far as I could see.

Reviews.Title: “Just what we had hoped for”
Reviews.Author: LondonMissMoneypenny
Reviews.Content: The Empress Zoe is a lovely small hotel. It is extremely well located for sightseeing in the Sultanahmet area of Istanbul. Our room, the "Honeymoon Suite" in the Maison Zoe part of the hotel was exactly as it looked on the website, it had a large (and comfortable bed) and the Hammam style bathroom was great. We had no real trouble with noise in this room, although you will hear the early call to prayer (currently at around 5am). This is not a flashy hotel but it is quirky, charming and the place to go if you want something with a bit of understated style (for example they provide organic shampoo and soap in the bathrooms which is made for the hotel). We loved the courtyard garden and were able to sit outside in the afternoons on most days - it is still a bit chilly in Istanbul at the moment. We found the service to be of exactly the right level - when we needed a restaurant reservation on the first night that was done for us, when we ran out of shampoo more was brought swiftly to our room, our airport taxi was booked for us in good time and with the advice to go early as President Obama was arriving on the day we left and roads were being closed. This hotel is not particularly cheap but then we found Istanbul to be generally more expensive that we thought it would be. I would definitely recommend this hotel and would go back.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing Zoe In Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: CDPARIS
Reviews.Content: The Empress Zoe hotel is very well suited to people looking for up-market hostel-style accomodation. Our room was very basic - sort of "false" old-world charm- and the hotel was noisy (it might be an idea to carpet the communal areas!).Although the garden was pleasant it was too chilly to sit out in the morning and the indoor breakfast room was a bit cramped at breakfast time. Service was reasonable but impersonal and rather unsmiling. All that came in at price tag of 125/Night... which we definitely felt was too much for what we were getting. We thought we were going to get something personal and special - but not so. We regret not having gone for a special offer at one of the bigger hotel chains. Also, on a more general note, we would definitely not recommend the Sultanahmet area of Istanbul. Its a bit like Disney World, very kitch, and the restaurants there operate a segregation policy between locals and tourists. We would therefore recommend trying to get a special offer at one of the bigger hotel chains in one of the less tourist-trap areas of Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “The wonderful Empress Zoe”
Reviews.Author: Opaldog
Reviews.Content: We just returned from an amazing vacation in Istanbul. Our stay at the Empress Zoe was nothing short of wonderful. We stayed in the Penthouse Suite which has a jaw dropping view of the Sea of Marmara/Bosphorus and the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya. The atmosphere was warm and friendly. The common rooms were comfortable and stylishly decorated. The house cats were a "touch of home", even though I have a dog at my house. The staff was cordial and helpful when needed, yet in no way intrusive. The breakfast was substantial enough so that if we didn't want to have lunch we didn't need to. It consisted of cereal, a variety of fruits, breads, simit, cheese, yogurt, a spinach filo type pastry, hard boiled egg, orange juice, coffee/tea, butter, jams and perhaps more, but that is what I remember. There was always space to eat in the different small common rooms. Breakfast was served between 8 and 11. In the evening we were able to bring our laptop down to the common rooms and sit in front of the fireplace and have a glass of wine and listen to music, generally jazz, while we checked our emails, etc. Our room (Penthouse Suite) was great. We had a private staircase with a skylight leading up to the room door. The living area was a good size furnished in what I would call a Turkish style. There was a small t.v. with Turkish stations and the BBC. We watched ocassionally, but wouldn't have missed it. The view was amazing, as I already mentioned. The Suite had a private terrace that had steps leading to the top of the roof to the main terrace. The bedroom was in a small area with a full closet with a large mirror. The bedroom window overlooked the garden of the hotel and other hotel rooms. There was a small kitchen area with a refrigerator and a coffeemaker with wine glasses, glasses and coffee/tea cups. There was a bottle of water waiting for us in the refrigerator and tea bags and instant coffee. We did not use these on our trip. The room was serviced every day with sheets and towels. We can't wait to go back. We loved Istanbul and the Empress Zoe. We highly recommend the hotel and the Penthouse Suite in particular

Reviews.Title: “Great location, quirky, variable rooms”
Reviews.Author: mmppwwzz
Reviews.Content: Stayed here with a group for four nights; I was the only single person in the group and was booked into a tiny 'twin' room with two single beds. The hotel is in a wonderful location in the Sultanahmet, right near Topkapi Palace, the Haggia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. On check in, I found the service to be warm and friendly and very accomodating. When there's such variation in the style of rooms, it's important to fully disclosure any potential issues with a guest room on check-in, but for some reason Turkish culture seems to avoid confrontation in this sort of situation (quite different from the traders at the Grand Bazaar.) Fortunately, as a single guy travelling with a bunch of couples, I wasn't in the room much and was able to hang out with other friends, but be warned there is a huge variation in the quality of rooms at this hotel. Goes with the territory as it's very much a quirky boutique hotel, but avoid, at all costs, the rooms at the top of the first set of spiral stairs which are: tiny, loud (basically on a loud cobblestone street corner), have insufficient blinds to cut out the street lights at night (one of which shines directly into your face), and a tiny bathroom and shower impossible for the average man to bathe properly. To be fair, the price for this room was lower than others in the hotel where friends were staying, but if I had an option, rather than get the cheapest room at the Empress Zoe, I would have spent the same money on a better room at an alternative place close by. On the positive side, there are wonderful common areas that are exotic and inviting with beautiful Turkish rugs, and have a 'Travels with my Aunt' Graeme Green old-fashioned feel to them. The staff are warm and understated, and the breakfast is great with unique Turkish cheeses and jams to try. There's also a wonderful outdoor garden, and beautiful views from a rooftop terrace. With other friends staying in the hotel, it's clear there are some beautiful rooms at this hotel. I wish I could remember some of the room numbers, since you do need to specify a specific room to be assured of a quality room - there's that much variation. If you ask for a room which faces the Bosphorous, you will have the best shot as it will be off the street, and higher up and away from the noise. And hopefully with a view of the Bosphorous thrown in.

Reviews.Title: “Very Turkish hotel in great location”
Reviews.Author: LynnDB
Reviews.Content: This is a beautiful, historical hotel in a great location. We had the top floor suite that has a very beautiful, rustic Turkish design. The front desk staff were very helpful and friendly. We enjoyed our stay. A couple of tips: Try to have afternoon tea at the Four Seasons. It's wonderful. Don't bother to look at rugs. The days of buying a nice rug for less than $1500 USD are gone. We waited until we got home and bought a much nicer rug in the States for less money.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful charming holte”
Reviews.Author: brazilianwanderlust
Reviews.Content: This is one of those rare hotels that, in my opinion, has it all: its location is ideal for first-time Istanbul tourists, it is unique and distinct and the atmosphere is perfect. I stayed over new year's with my wife on the penthouse suite, which faces three directions and we absolutely loved it. I could even stare at Aya Sofia from my bed! Of course, this may not be for those who seek design hotel luxury and impersonality of big chains. Here, the floors squeak, there are cats around, there is no elevator. For me, these are all positive points. The only thing I could have used was a bigger bed, since both my wife and I are tall. It's true that you hear the call for prayer three times a day, but I guess all mosques in the city have loudspeakers. And the sound of the call for prayer is entrancing, so I wouldn't rate it as a downside. If you are looking for a charming place in historic Istanbul, this is it. If you're a nighttime person, or someone on a second or third trip to the city, then you have probably seen the sights around here, and could consider staying in Beyoglu for restaurants and bars or somewhere nice along the Bosphorus for a change.

Reviews.Title: “History at your feet!”
Reviews.Author: lamerazure
Reviews.Content: Empress Zoe is a nice property, ideally situated in the middle of the Sultanhamet district. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and Topkapi Palace are an easy walk (remember to pack practical shoesâ€¦ steep cobblestone streets are the norm). It is a unique alternative to the other large hotels, like the Four Seasons, which is a block away. We stayed in the spacious Cistern Suite, complete with an enormous marble shower/hammam. Because it is partially underground, it provides a certain sound barrier to the morning calls to prayer. The common areas are very inviting and guests seem to gravitate to the fireplace/bar area. It was quite cold during our stay, so a fire was constantly burning. Cats are curled up on benches and authentic Turkish dÃ©cor graces the walls. No spa facilities are on the premises, but an excellent masseuse (Veronica) is available at the Four Seasons. You seem far removed from civilization without internet and international television (a welcomed change, at times). A rather sparse breakfast is included. At best, I would classify it as continental. The spiral staircase is extremely narrow but they are happy to assist you with luggage. I highly recommend booking a car to pick you up (we did), as arrival can be a painful experience. Be wary of all yellow cabs. If you decide to take a cab to Ataturk on your return, determine the price in advance. I would not describe this hotel as a luxurious accommodation, but it sufficed and proved to be a good choice for our visit to Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “...cozy hotel for an Istanbul snowstorm!”
Reviews.Author: EverHopefulTraveller
Reviews.Content: This is a lovely and interesting hotel-much like the city. The Zoe is also very, very convenient. All of the culture and attractions are within a walk or short tram-ride away. It snowed a blizzard while I was there but the hotel was very cozy with a lovely open fire. The rooms are individual and different but be aware that there is a narrow, wrought-iron spiral staircase in the main building-fun as long as you don't mind! Breakfast was plentiful and good quality and the staff were very helpful.

Reviews.Title: “A gem in Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: chuston
Reviews.Content: We loved Empress Zoe, but we did not love Istanbul. We stayed on the European side after reading that it was like being in Europe. Sadly it was not. The city is very old, with great history, and wonderful mosques, but beyond that we found that other cities had much more to offer. The best part of our stay there was Empress Zoe. It is a quaint hotel, with a wonderful feel. There are lots of stairs, so if you have a hard time with stairs, don't stay there. I would highly recommend this hotel, if you are looking for a great place in Istanbul. It is located just around the corner from the Four Seasons and just minutes from The Blue Mosque, the Haga Sofia, and other touristy sites. We boarded the train that runs through town and took it everywhere. We looked for rugs, but felt like we were being taken for a ride. The Empress Zoe was able to recommend a place where we would be treated fairly.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, but a few reservations”
Reviews.Author: davidtinney
Reviews.Content: Just returned from four nights at the Empress, and my partner has stayed there twice before. It is a lovely, cozy, and very friendly small hotel with a number of docile, friendly cats who want to be your friend. The staff are absolutely stellar and professional. The breakfasts are good (and Turkish!), but modest. The rooms are pretty tiny and please be aware that only the family rooms actually have TVs. My only real objection is the call to prayer in the morning. The hotel is totally quiet, but there is a small mosque situated at the back of the hotel and unless you are deaf you will be awoken (although only for 5 minutes), by the call at 6:30am. Stairs never killed anyone! David

Reviews.Title: “If you love stairs, you will love this hotel...”
Reviews.Author: lovesumba
Reviews.Content: I wanted to love this hotel. The pictures are beautiful and it is a lovely property. To get to your room, you need to go up a staircase that is wide enough for one person and winds twice - frankly that freaked me out. The hotel gave me a hard time because they said they tell us on their web site that there are a lot of stairs...but what they don't tell you is that you need to use this staircase to enter the hotel. I refused, and they told me about another entrance, but made me feel really bad about using it. Once you get upstairs, the hotel is charming... the rooms are small, and the windows are not double paned, so you do hear a lot of street noise. We ultimately left the hotel because of the street noise. The location is great, and the prices are competitive. I would recommend this hotel if noise does not both you, and if you like stairs.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely little place!”
Reviews.Author: wakanan
Reviews.Content: I stayed at single room for 2 nights. Room is small but well designed and bed is semi-double. They give you small olive oil soap, which did make my skin very smooth:) There is a garden and bar where you have breakfast or late night coffee or more, and I felt great to be back here in the end of the day. Breakfast is very good, you can expect a little more than ordinary Turkish breakfast in this hotel. Hotel staff are very efficient and friendly. Two cats almost live there and greet you like one of hotel staff. As precautioned on their website, the spiral stairs are bit of challenge and you have to wait while anyone else is coming up/down. But it's also fun to take turns with other guests. All in all, Empress Zoe is a lovely little place and I definitely want to stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “A Turkish Delight”
Reviews.Author: Hetta_8
Reviews.Content: Hotel Empress Zoe is situated in the historic Sulthahmet area of Istanbul and wonderfully located for walking to the major attractions of this fabulous city. The hotel is quite funky with fascinating wall paintings and decorated with turkish textiles and art works. The attractive internal archaelogical garden, where the delicious breakfast can be enjoyed, borders an historic turkish bath house. There are 25 rooms in several old style buildings, all individually decorated and most with hamam style bathrooms. The roof top views include the sea of Marmara, Aghi Sophia and the Blue Mosque. A bar service is available in the evenings. The hotel in not for those after a very traditiona establishment, but a delight for those wanting a different experience and enjoy accommodation that reflects the culture of the city visited.There are no lifts and a spiral staircase from the quaint reception area, may challenge. Rates are very modest for the charm and facilities on offer Hetta Australia

Reviews.Title: “Many positives, some negatives”
Reviews.Author: TNHoo
Reviews.Content: My wife and I just returned from a 3 night stay here. We were very pleased with this hotel as the positives outweighed the negatives. Positives: Location- You can walk to the Haggia Sofia and Blue Mosque easlily. Rooms-Cramped, but adequate. Staff- EXTREMELY nice and helpful. Each and every person was was incredibly hospitable. They really go out of their way to be of help. Two of the night staff were even going to give us a concert with their local instruments. The staff makes this hotel. Breakfast- Delicious spread with memorable preserves. Garden Area- Very nice for relaxing. Negatives: Winding metal staircases- No elevators which makes things interesting when staying on the top floor (4 flights up a spiral staircase). Noise- Be prepared to be awakened at 5 AM with the Muslim call to prayer. The speakers from the mosques seem to be just outside your room. I doubt that you can avoid this anywhere though. Price- Probably not that bad given the location.

Reviews.Title: “Charming Boutique Hotel”
Reviews.Author: AustralianJulie
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 5 nights in September 2008. Fabulous location near all the major sights, & right next to the 4 Seasons so when you get lost you can ask directions & everyone knows where that is. We stayed in a garden suite which was just fabulous.The garden was very nice as were the 2 roof terraces. The only thing I did not like was the call to prayer which woke us up each morning at 4.30 am but there are so mant mosques in Istanbul you can't escape. And if you don't plan to buy a carpet be ready to resist the carpet touts. If you do, make sure you look around at home first to see if you are really going to save money. Istanbul is a truly remarkable city.

Reviews.Title: “The right location for seeing Istanbul.”
Reviews.Author: OnOurWay038
Reviews.Content: This was the perfect spot for us in Istanbul. Our room was lovely, looking out over the enclosed garden. The breakfasts were great, and the staff was most helpful in recommending restaurants, of which there were plenty in easy walking distance. Everything at the hotel was spotless and well tended. I was totally spoiled by the bowls of fresh pomegranate seeds every morning at the breakfast. We were within short walks of the Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque, and then a slightly longer walk to the easy Istanbul tram. The neighborhood was most pleasant. The hotel is actually a number of large houses, joined, so you do go up and down many stairs - on the top of one house was a roof garden, with a spectacular vista of the Sea of Marmara.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely, Charming Oasis Near Top Historical Sights of Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: ambough
Reviews.Content: Great location (10 min. walk) from all major sights in Sultanhamet district, such as the Blue Mosque, Hayia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and much more. Deluxe top-floor rooms are smaller than American-style hotels, but offer nice marble baths, private terraces with lovely views of the Bosphorus Straights, and charming Turkish style. Excellent breakfast buffet with wide selection of fresh fruit, cheese, olives, meat, breads, and beautiful private garden for dining or evening cocktails. Staff members were always helpful and professional, and provided info on nice restaurants, ATM locations, and cultural/historical background of the city. Transfers from the Ataturk airport are available for a small fee. I plan to return to Istanbul again as soon as possible, and would highly recommend this hotel to friends and family.

Reviews.Title: “Oh no......I agree with the Daily Mail!”
Reviews.Author: CabbagesAhoy
Reviews.Content: Booked this hotel after it was recommended in 'The Daily Mail'. In my defence (!) I only buy it for Johnathan Cainer's astrology and the travel section - which enthused about this little hotel. The hotel did not disappoint. Beautifully complimenting the old district of Istanbul that it's in it's interior is a joy - spiral staircases, evil eyes cascading from big mirrors and lots of local art. The garden is a perfect spot for a large buffet breakfast - lots of bread, jams, cheeses and those big fat sun gorged tomatoes that you only seem to get abroad. We had a double room at the front . Again it was beautifully decorated. There was no TV but this hardly mattered when the balcony was the perfect spot for a bit of 'street soap opera' watching. Like many people here on this site I loved the 4.30 mosque call. It's actually very calming and a wonderful slice of something different. The bathroom in our room was small and the shower cubicle very small BUT it was powerful shower and the air con was fabulous! I have been in so many hotels where the air con was broken or useless - This worked brilliantly. What really sets this hotel apart though is the staff - All of them friendly and knowledgable and so accomodating. It really was the perfect base to explore Istanbul from. I would stay there again in a heartbeat - and for probably the first time ever - me and the Daily Mail agree!

Reviews.Title: “A little bit of heaven”
Reviews.Author: DrJimbob
Reviews.Content: We have been to Istanbul twice, and the first stay at the Empress Zoe in October of 2006 was enough to convince us to try them again, on a second trip on September of 2007. The hotel delivered in spades both times. We have stayed in a double each time. The rooms are of modest size, with plenty of storage (a bit armoire with a small safe in each room), a lovely canopy bed with a charming kilim at the top, a small outside mini-terrace which overlooks the garden space (and the second time, with a magnificent view of the Bosporus). Bathrooms are well appointed, with decent hot water and a local brand of olive oil soap. The garden, where breakfast is served, is converted from an old Turkish hamam, and has been decked out with a variety of beautiful trees and plants. The breakfast itself is generous, the standard Turkish fare of white cheese, yogurt, olives, tomatoes and cucumbers, jams and fresh fruit, supplemented with a variety of breads both Turkish and Western, small spanakopitas, and a few other goodies. There is also a roofdeck, with an unobstructed view of the Bosporus which achieves fairy-tale romantic status with a bottle of raki and a moonlit night. The location is impeccable, sitting as it does in the edges of Sultanahmet, in the shadow of the Four Seasons and Topkapi Palace. The staff are all very nice and quite helpful. The hotel is decked out with a colorful mix of Byzantine-inspired decor and quirky but not out of place modern touches. The major challenge is the windy spiral staircase which you must manage on a daily basis to get into and out of the rooms. But the price is very reasonable and the rooms pretty near to perfect.

Reviews.Title: “fantastic stay”
Reviews.Author: freedman121
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Empress Zoe for six nights, and everything (except the room size; our ideal room, the garden suite, was already taken) was perfect. Our bags got lost on the flight to Turkey and the hotel staff was wonderful, calling the airlines every day in an attempt to get them back for us. The breakfasts were absolutely to die for, and the overall atmosphere of the hotel was very nice; the garden was lovely although we did not spend time there because the December weather is too cold for that.

Reviews.Title: “A jewel!”
Reviews.Author: take-your-time
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 5 nights at the Empress Zoe in the Chez Zoe Grand Deluxe Garden Suite. We chose this suite after trawling through tripadvisor reviews and some discussion with the property directly. The suite is HUGE and as fabulous as it sounds and looks on the website (which is very comprehensive). It feels quite private and having the private entrance off the road behind was fantastic as you could avoid negotiating the windy staircases to get to the main reception. The suite had views of the gorgeous garden and hamman (from a balcony) and there was a fabulous view of the bosphorous from the private roof terrace shared by the 4 suites in this villa. The location in Sultanahmet is brilliant and the property is not at all ruined by the new Four Seasons wing that has obliterated views of the Mosque. Sure, it would have been amazing to have this view but it did not affect the quality of the accommodation or the other wonderful views toward the Bosphorous. Staff at the Zoe were not exactly fantastic or helpful, but there was not really that much need to interact with them. Overall this is a great and really quite unique property in the heart of a wonderful city.

Reviews.Title: “Atmospheric Zoe”
Reviews.Author: Ali_Aus
Reviews.Content: Stayed in the Empress Zoe for two nights on our final stop in Istanbul.. Only had the choice of a garden terrace room, which was pricey, but worth the money. The front reception staff are a little frosty, but helpful and efficient, so really can't complain. The room was massive by Istanbul standards! Two rooms - three single beds and a double bed on a cute raised platform, and all the comforts you would need. Had a small kitchenette area, including fridge and table. This lead out to the best part, a balcony overlooking a lovely garden below. The bathroom was small, but impressive. The shower area was set up like a Turkish bath, which was very cute. For those of you who don't like stairs, then this is definitely NOT the place for you! Empress Zoe is a very lovingly and careful kept in the original style of the building, and is a rare find. It is very cute and cosy, and is perfect for those wanting a truly authentic and original hotel in the heart of the tourist area of Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “Beware which room you get”
Reviews.Author: ambermaine
Reviews.Content: The location is fantastic, the hotel very idiosyncratic, breakfasts good and staff very friendly and helpful. However, our four night stay had two distinct parts to it. Our first night was in the Penthouse Suite, which had fabulous views, a comfortable sofa and chair, and a lovely private roof terrace. Although it was up 75 stairs, the view and room made the climb well worthwhile, and we'd definitely book that room again. Because they were very full, however, we had to move to another room for the next three nights. This was the family suite, which was quite a good size, with a double bed, two singles and a cot. However, it was like a dungeon in comparison with the first room, as the decor was very dark and the three windows are covered with creeper. No daylight at all can penetrate into the room, and it's impossible to see out. Even with the lights on, the room is very gloomy. There are no chairs to sit on, and it is generally pretty uncomfortable. Unfortunately, there are no comfy seats elsewhere in the hotel, so not good for relaxing after a hard day seeing Istanbul's fantastic sights. So - book the Penthouse Suite and have a great stay. Don't book the Family Suite, and check when you book whether the windows are covered with creeper! Some rooms have balconies, and some have private terraces, so be very careful which one you get.

Reviews.Title: “A giid choice, overall”
Reviews.Author: tracyk45
Reviews.Content: We (three females) stayed for a week at the EZ this April. We agree with many of the positives in other reviews: great breakfasts (never found simit as good anywhere else in Turkey), loved the cats and the gardens, views, etc. The place is certainly not designed for anyone who has trouble climbing stairs and one of our party did...we had not only the much discussed iron spiral staircase but three other flights of stairs to get to our room. But the location is fabulous and though not cheap, the value is good. So overall we had a good experience. But there are some things that need to be addressed by management. For the first 5 nights we stayed in the Maisonette and we echo the things said by others about the views, etc. It was wonderful to sit on the terrace and watch the sun go down over the Sea of Marmara! Problems: We happened to be there during ANZAC week when the street (which has youth hostels on it) was overflowing with Aussies and Kiwis...celebrating until all hours (5AM?!) and making an unholy racket. Not the EZ's fault, but very off-putting all the same. Don't come during that period!! The other issues include a staff that was generall helpful but seemed unaware of certain tourist facts. For example, we told them we were leaving to get a cab for the Dolmabache palace on Thursday AM. They got us a cab, waved us away, and we found that the palace is closed on Thursdays. Wouldn't you think the folks at EZ would know that since it is a major attraction?? Second: We asked them to get us a cab to another major site (Suleiman Mosque) and when we got there we found it was closed for repairs and had been for weeks. Third: Same story with the Pera Palace hotel...cab ride only to find out it was closed for renovations and had been for some time. The staff should have known these things and been able to advise us before we set off for costly rides in the horrendous Istanbul traffic. For our last two nights we had to move to a double and a single. When one of our party complained about the ants coming in the windows on to her bed (and on to her!) she was told that it was unavoidable because of the ivy and that they would send up some powder ant poison. That never happened. I think I would stay again at EZ (though in a different week!) but I do think that the management needs to train their employees better in order to provide the kind of city information that front desks should be able to provide. Oh-- also don't believe the old guide books that say there is a large terrace where you can eat breakfast and have evening drinks. That has been converted into another guest room. (If you want the evening views, go have a drink at the nearby Seven Hills Hotel....)

Reviews.Title: “Small but fine”
Reviews.Author: nurseintheair
Reviews.Content: We booked the "budget room" at the Empress, and expected it to be small. We were not disappointed. It is very, very small. We had to be creative about finding room for our luggage , but with some shoving and piling, it worked. This room is for budget minded people who want an authentic hotel and are willing to put up with a fair amount of cramming and some street noise. The common areas of the hotel are lovely. Cozy breakfast area (many folks eat in the garden) which becomes the bar in the evening; tasteful reception area with some resources for the traveler; resident cats who might model for still life shots. The staff is helpful. The hotel is very convenient to the main attractions and the metro. Surrounding the hotel are numerous cafes and shops, and there is a small grocery across the street. We became friendly with the many touts outside and were not especially bothered by the hard sell tactics typical of the region, although I did not appreciate the repeated subtle attempts of one of the hotel staff to channel us to a rug store. Down the street toward the water, on the corner is a great barber shop, where you can get an excellent haircut without appointment. Nicely appointed hotel in a very convenient location. Would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Empress Zoe - Highly recommended by this solo traveler”
Reviews.Author: MoutonNoir
Reviews.Content: A well-run and charming hotel in the heart of Old Istanbul. The staff is attentive and the accommodations are unique.

Reviews.Title: “Definitely an Empress!”
Reviews.Author: MAB225
Reviews.Content: The Empress Zoe is all about location, location, location. From the roof top you can view the Bosphorus, look down the local street full of great restaurants, and around the corner is the Topaki Palace to the right and further down the street and around the corner to the left is the Blue Mosque. What could be better! The hotel is "owner operated and Ann Nevans is fantastic and the staff is very helpful. The breakfasts (included in the room cost) are homemade and delicious and can be eaten in the lovely garden or inside in the breakfast rooms. The hotel is not for folks with bad knees as there are lots of stairs depending on which of the three Ottoman homes your room is located in. But on the plus side they do have garden level rooms and porters to help with the luggage! We spent one week in this hotel and viewed other hotels in the area and were extremely happy with our choice of Empress Zoe. Please look it up on the web and see more photos. Showing some of the paintings on the wall and the garden for your reviewing...

Reviews.Title: “Empress Zoe was great!”
Reviews.Author: 8vex8
Reviews.Content: Add me to the list of great reviews for Empress Zoe! Unfortunately we had only one night in Istanbul, but we spent it at this wonderful little hotel. The front desk was very helpful in suggesting what to do during our short stay. The detailing throughout the hotel was exquisite, and the garden was beautiful. Stayed in the Cistern Suite, which was wonderfully decorated, with a great shower. Breakfast was great - lots of Turkish cheeses and olives, pastries, juices, fruits and cereals. If I learned one thing - it's that I must return to Istanbul and the Empress Zoe!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Stay at the Empress Zoe”
Reviews.Author: nicolle_a
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a million miles away from your cookie cutter/formulaic hotels. Itâ€™s full of character/itâ€™s quirky and it has that old world feeling to it. My room was charming and cosy at the same time and also came with a wonderful view. The bathrooms are modern in the ways that counted, clean and are stocked with nice toiletries. One thingâ€¦the shower IS tiny (maybe the smallest one Iâ€™ve encountered anywhere) but overall not a big deal. What is a bigger deal is the call to prayer in the middle of the night every night. (I defy anyone to sleep through that, earplugs or not). However, I would guess the same would hold true wherever you stay in Sultanahmet and I donâ€™t, for a minute, regret staying here as opposed to Taksim. The hotel is within minutes of all the top tourist sites which meant I could go back to the hotel easily in the middle of the day for a rest/get an umbrella/get an extra sweater/or drop off my many purchases! Itâ€™s also within a few minutes of a tram stop (which gives you easy access to the Grand Bazaar/Spice Bazaar/Taksim). The hotel couldnâ€™t have been better positioned. Also, the area felt really safe even when I walked back to the hotel at night by myself. They serve up a really nice/varied breakfast which means you can actually eat a healthy breakfast (fresh fruit/cereal. Their oranges were really sweet and especially nice.) But they have something for everyone, including freshly baked goods, boiled eggs//tomatoes/feta cheese/cucumbers. For those of you who are addicted to the internet like me, there isnâ€™t a computer terminal for guestsâ€™ use there but they do have free wi-fi in the bar/breakfast area. Lastly, I found the staff to be very helpful/efficient. I always figure itâ€™s a good sign when you e-mail a hotel and they respond to you within hours as opposed to days, which was always my experience with the Empress Zoe. And that high level of service was maintained by the staff throughout my entire stay. One last thing, if youâ€™re a big shopper like me, donâ€™t miss out on the Arasta Bazaar, located only a few minutes away from the hotel (adjacent to the Blue Mosque). Although itâ€™s a lot smaller than the Grand Bazaar, itâ€™s also much less hectic, and unlike the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar, is open on Sundays.

Reviews.Title: “Great for a short break”
Reviews.Author: fly2steve
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Empress Zoe for 3 nights, the rooms are traditionally decorated and the bed was very comfortable the only bad point about the room is that the shower is very small. The hotel employees are very helpful, i emailed them several times to organise things to do when we were there and they booked and oragnised my requsets and emailed me back very quickly. we booked transport to pick us up from the airport through the hotel, it was very efficient and gave us peace of mind knowing that it would take us straight to the hotel and it was about the same price as a taxi. the location is excellent for the historic area near to the topkai palace and the blue mosque. The hotel organised a guide for two days (Cengiz) who was very knowledgable and well worth using. Istanbul is a wonderful city and i would recommend the empress zoe to anyone who is visiting the city.

Reviews.Title: “Warm & Friendly, Outstanding Staff”
Reviews.Author: AJamesAsheville
Reviews.Content: My friend and I just returned from a week in Istanbul and consider ourselves so so lucky to have selected The Hotel Empress Zoe as our hotel there. We selected the hotel primarily because of the location - just next to the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, and the Topaki Palace. What a bonus to find the hotel staff: Layla, Hasan, Hayati, and Binnur such lovely and hospitable people. The hotel has just about 24 cozy rooms and decorated in "traditional Istanbul" . We felt like we came home to friends after each day of touring Istanbul. The hotel bar served as a gathering place for all guests where the charming bartender, Suleyman, not only provided whatever you needed in terms of libations, but also soothed your soul with jazz from around the world. It didn't hurt that he kept the fire burning and the lights low to maintain that Istanbul mood. We were always so comfortable in Suleyman's bar that we sometimes forgot to go to dinner. I commend Anna, the hotel owner , on finding such an attentive staff. It is clear that everyone who works there truly loves their job. I'll certainly return. You can email for reservations at [--]

Reviews.Title: “My stay confirmed the other reviews”
Reviews.Author: owlyong
Reviews.Content: My family was in EZ for Christmas. I have chosen this hotel based solely on existing reviews. We stayed for 5 nites. 99% of the good reviews are true. Especially the small fellow by the name of Omer will happily carried your heavy luggage up the narrow spiral staircase. The family room although small was sufficient for us including 2 teenage children. Towels did fell from the sky. Binnur and Hayati were there. All sights were within walking distance. Other review on Istanbul - People in Istanbul are very friendly although some may "look rowdy". Istanbul is a safe place for tourists even at night. BUT be careful when you are in Grand Bazaar where prices can be ridiculously jacked up especially copied maps/pictures/sketches. Try Taksim area, they are cheap there, YTL3 to 5 for a copied old Istanbul map. Also beware if you visit Galata Tower to watch Belly-dancing, the food and show is good but in winter do not allow the usher to keep your coat, he will at the end of the show demand YTL5 per piece for a supposedly free service. Also this same usher will double up as a camera man capturing photographs of you with the belly dancer BUT each photograph will cost you YTL15.

Reviews.Title: “Loved Empress Zoe”
Reviews.Author: Lakita
Reviews.Content: My friend and I stayed at the Empress Zoe for five nights. The first night we stayed in the Chez Zoe Deluxe Garden Suite, followed by four nights in the Penthouse Suite. Both of the rooms were beautifully decorated and the views in the Penthouse Suite were amazing. The hotel has an excellent staff. We became friends with Hayati (front desk) and Suleyman (bartender). They gave us advice on shopping, restaurants, and our itinerary. At night they took us out to different clubs/bars that aren't frequented by tourists. It was great to hear some local talent and get a sense of the real Istanbul. We spent 2.5 weeks in Turkey and Greece, and Empress Zoe was the best hotel hands down. I would highly recommend them to anyone and look forward to staying there again. Lakita

Reviews.Title: “We Wanted to Take Empress Zoe's Cats Home With Us”
Reviews.Author: ChristopherPrusaski
Reviews.Content: My partner and I just returned from an 8-night stay in Istanbul (our first trip to Turkey). We had an amazing time, due, in part, to the lovely hotel with fabulous staff where we chose to stay: the Empress Zoe (referred to below as â€œEZâ€�). We booked the EZ directly over the â€˜phone (with email confirmation) after speaking with the EZâ€™s owner, Ann, who assisted us in choosing the right room. We chose the Penthouse Suite, and paid the winter rate (posted on the hotelâ€™s website) of EU140 per night (the EZ gave us a 10 percent discount off the entire bill b/c we paid in cash). LOCATION: The EZ is located in Sultanahmet, which is the old neighborhood of Istanbul where most of the major sites are concentrated: the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Topkapi Palace, Archaeology Museum, to name only a few. The EZ is only a few minutesâ€™ walk to all of the aforementioned places. This neighborhood is also only a 10-minute walk to the Bazaar District and a 20-minute walk to Eminonu, where you catch the ferries for Bosphorus tours and to go all over Istanbul. There is a bodega right across the street from the EZ which sells groceries and alcohol. There is also a laundromat about 30 meters from the EZ, which washed and folded our laundry for only 4YTL per kilo (cheap) within a matter of a few hours. Moreover, the neighborhood is extremely safe (as we found most of the city to be) to walk at all hours. The streets are full of activity until late, and the presence of police officers (several of whom we asked for directions and were actually really helpful) is impressive. TRANSPORT TO THE EZ: We opted to choose the hotelâ€™s transport service from Ataturk Intâ€™l Airport, which costs EU26, and which was added to our bill. A really nice kid was waiting for us when we left customs with our name on a sign. A new, clean van transported us to the EZ. The driver was another really nice guy who bent over backwards to speak English to us and enthusiastically tell us about his city. Anyway, the EU26 is a good deal, since our taxi ride back to the airport at the end of the trip was around YTL35 (with no trafficâ€”would have been a LOT more at peak times). OVERVIEW OF THE EZ: The EZ is an Ottoman Hotel (as described in the travel guides) comprised of several old buildings connected by a common garden, which is beautiful. In short, the EZ is elegant yet cozy, and impeccably clean. There are only approx. 20 rooms. Certainly the nicest thing about a hotel this size is the fact that staff get to know you quickly and the service is very personal. For example, when returning to the EZ, the people who staffed the front desk knew us and chatted us up and asked us if we had a nice day, etc., as did the bartender. Finally, as the Tripadvisor reviews repeat, there is indeed no elevator. However, there is no great labyrinth of stairs, so this was not an issue for us. The hotel staff took all of our bags to our room (and later brought them down), so we never had to carry anything up/downstairs. THE ROOM: We stayed in Room 401, the Penthouse Suite. The room is approx. 400 square feet (my visual estimate), which is accessed from private stairs on the third floor. There is a living room with sofa, small TV (lots of Turkish channels, plus CNN and BBC), a desk with several chairs, and a bar with good-size refrigerator (and two big empty cabinets next to the â€˜fridge). The bedroom is a small separate area (not much bigger than the double bed) separated from the living room by a little curtain, and which contains a spacious closet with a mini safe. The entire suite (including bedroom) is surrounded by windows with nice views of the sea and the neighborhood. There is a separate day-bed in the living room, which is very comfortable and upon which I took a few afternoon siestas. The window curtains can completely black-out the room if you want to sleep late. A large bottle of water was in the room upon check-in, and we were able to stock up later at the bodega across the street. The bathroom was great! As the photos weâ€™re posting show, the shower is a little hamam surrounded on three sides with a sitting area, with both a showerhead (great water pressureâ€”we miss it) and a cistern. So you can take a shower and/or sit and â€œbatheâ€� and pour water over yourself with the silver bowl. Two big cabinets are under the sink and will hold a ton of toiletries. The hotel also provides olive-oil soap (we loaded up on this stuff at the airport) and shampoo. New towels (including 4 bathtowels) were provided every day. The bathroom also has a heated rack, in case you need to dry anything. A door from the room leads to a cute private porch with a table and chairs, which has a partial view of the Blue Mosque at night. Stairs from the porch lead up to a rooftop sitting area, with several tables and breathtaking views of the sea, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, and the neighborhood. This area is shared by a few rooms, and we met some nice people up there. INTERNET: There is WIFI located in the breakfast area/bar downstairs, which works great. We were actually able to catch a weak signal in our room, so we could surf the web (albeit slowly). BREAKFAST: We enjoyed the EZâ€™s breakfast (included in the rate) most each morning. The breakfast is tasty (and pretty healthy) and includes coffee, tea, juice, olives, tomatoes, cucumbers, yoghurt, cereal, and various breads. STAFF: Special thanks to the EZâ€™s owner, Ann, and her associates, Leyla and Hayati, all of whom were so professional and kind to us. And props to the bartender, whose name I regrettably forgot, who was really cool and greeted us each night with a big smile. Thanks also to the older gentleman who had to schlep our heavy bags downstairs on a Sunday at 4:45 am (we had an early flight!), and did so with a smile on his face, and wished us a good trip. This is Service. Ann recommended a great local (read: not tourist prices) kebab place called â€œBuhara Ocakbasiâ€�, which is a 10 minute walk, and where we ended up eating twice. Another fabulous restaurant which is only a few doors down from the EZ is â€œAlbura.â€� NOISE ISSUES OR LACK THEREOF: Reading the other reviews below, I was prepared to be located next to a hotel construction site. We did not have any issues with noise (other than the call to prayer, which is very cool when you first hear it and we got used to it and were able to sleep through it after a while). WE LOVE CATS: First of all, we were blown away at how many cats live on the street in Istanbul. Some of the kittens will come right up to you if you call them and start nuzzling you. There are three male cats who live at EZ. Iâ€™m talking about them because we miss them already, so if youâ€™re not a cat fan, you can end the review here. Two are yellow cats (one is 15 years old, we were told, and the other is 2), and another is a black cat who we only saw a few times. The two yellow cats would sleep next to each other every night in the breakfast area, and we pet them every night when we returned. The old one will crawl right into your lap and sleep there if you want him to. The little guy, whom we called â€œPashaâ€� (Ann told us his nameâ€”I forgot itâ€”sorry), would be sitting on our porch every morning when we woke up. So after a few days, the first thing we did was check to see if Pasha was there. So I guess the reason why Iâ€™m boring you with this cat story is because, as cat lovers, we sort of were able to temporarily â€œadoptâ€� these cats during our stay at the EZ, and their presence made us happy, so there you go. If you made it this far, thanks for reading. As with all my reviews, feel free to email with any questions.

Reviews.Title: “Real Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: lightpackers
Reviews.Content: The best part of the Zoe is the staff, front desk, including the owner, make you feel at home. Qquestions answered, suggestions given with a smile, and a warm five-day welcome. The porters, bless them, for lugging four heavy bags (pre-cruise) to our Honeymoon Double. Good bed, great shower and lots of towels (the number seemed to multiply in the dark). This is not The Four Season, which is around the corner, but felt, instead, closer to staying where we were - Istanbul, and the original part of the city, to boot. The decor, breakfast, all were in keeping with the area. Great location for walkable access to major sites - Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Topkapi, etc. Our room contained suggestions for dining, two of which we tried and were great - Hamdi and walkable Balikci Sabahattin Fish Restaurant. Don't be put off by stories of nearby hotel construction. Who sleeps past 8:30 in exciting Istanbul, nor sleeps before 6:00 PM. Not a problem at all. We had a young guide for two half-day walking tours - Selchuk Sebilcioglu - faultless English and most knowledgeable (www.tourguideturkey.net). He was recommended by a member of the night staff and we recommend him highly. Finally, should you stay, say "Hello" to Binnur Isildar at the hotel from Helen and Bruce.

Reviews.Title: “Charming Hotel”
Reviews.Author: EPY
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent four nights in the Terrace Suite at the beginning of October. We loved the the hotel's charm, character and warmth of the staff. The Terrace Suite is on the top floor of Villa Zoe and is made up of a bedroom, ample bathroom, and second room with two comfortable day beds. In addition, the suite has a small outdoor porch area so one can sit outside. From the porch, one has a limited view of the Sea of Marmara in the distance and we watched the ships sail in and out of Istanbul. The hotel's garden is a delight and beside the many plants and trees contains garden tables and chairs which is where guests have their breakfasts. The breakfast food--very good and plentiful--reflects a combination of both "western" tastes (e.g., eggs, juice) and Turkish food (e.g., yohurt, cucumbers and feta cheese). In addition, the staff was truly outstanding, very helpful and made great suggestions on what to see and where to dine. My wife and I felt right at home! However, I would say to anyone who is now thinking about booking the hotel to ask themselves if they imagine that the construction noise next door at the Four Seasons may disrupt their enjoyment of such a wonderful hotel. Yes, the construction is an all day affair--from about 8:30 until 6:00--and if you are the type who likes to spend time in your hotel room during the day then you should think twice about making a reservation. But, if you are the type who is out the door (relatively) early in the morning and doesn't return until late afternoon/evening, then I would HIGHLY recommend booking the Hotel Express Zoe.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing haven in great location”
Reviews.Author: loveturkeyYorkshire
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Cistern Suite - great room, amazing bathroom experience - marble seats, power shower beautiful natrual herbal soap provided - like a mini-hamam. Sitting area and terrace lovely - complete with friendly and well cared for cat Jasper! We had no problems with noise at all - in fact found it eeriely quiet at night for a great city. Yes there is construction work at the Four Seasons but they didnt start till around 8.30 and by then we were either having breakfast or on the way out- the noise is no more than normal city noise - I am a light sleeper and very sensitive to noise and had no problems with my usual ear plugs. Staff helpful, breakfast very enjoyable in courtyard garden. Room safe didnt work and wasnt fixed during our stay, but we would certainly stay here again and would recommend to anyone - spiral staircases I normally dislike but found these not a problem. 360 restaurant is over rated - if you like a seventies style night club environment in which to eat over priced pizzas its your spot - far beeter food and turkish dining experiences available....

Reviews.Title: “Great location, lovely hotel”
Reviews.Author: nickjmcd
Reviews.Content: Empress Zoe is a great hotel - 5 minutes walk from the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia and our room looked out over the Bosporus. It's got very friendly staff, was clean and has been decorated beautifully but simply in traditional Turkish style. We got a 10% discount for paying in cash, which you can do in any currency you like. You eat breakfast in a densely-planted quiet courtyard and can get drinks there in the evening or take them up to the roof-top terrace which has views of the Blue Mosque, Bosporus etc. 50 times nicer than staying in any chain hotel

Reviews.Title: “lovely but loud for now”
Reviews.Author: mmwanderer
Reviews.Content: The Empress Zoe is a charming property, located in the heart of the tourist district of Istanbul. I would have enjoyed rating them higher, but construction noise from Four Seasons (already discussed elsewhere, here) made the stay less than ideal. The hotel is apparently owned by an American - but she was not around during our stay. The staff had sufficient, but not quite fluent English. They were usually helpful and polite. Meal referrals - good food, but prices a little steep. Still less than the high-end hotels, though. Merchant referrals --- reasonable. Happy to say they steered me to a reasonably good rug dealer. Breakfast - minimal, but fresh. Wonting for protein - but that's hardly an unusual problem. Tour referrals - okay - but my tour ran much later than it was supposed to, and the guide skipped one minor advertised part. Getting back to the hotel, itself ---- room was reasonably well furnished. TV options were very limited (but who goes to Istanbul to watch TV?) The "authentic" Turkish decor wasn't quite what I was expecting from photos ---- but it was not a deal breaker.

Reviews.Title: “a gem with a beautiful garden”
Reviews.Author: abby7
Reviews.Content: This hotel was even better than we hoped.. We stayed in a garden suite which had two rooms separated by a long hall. The living room looked over the lovely garden. It had a huge bathroom with a seat in the shower. We had been worried about the stairs based on past reviews but our room was up only a few stairs and could be entered from a separate entrance. The hotel oozed charm and the staff were very helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely LIttle Boutique Hotel”
Reviews.Author: tobyteabag
Reviews.Content: We chose the Zoe for the first 3 nights of our honeymoon and it was lovely! From the street it is a very unassuming hotel in the Sultanahmet district of Istanbul but from its roof terrace there are wonderful views of the Bosphorus and the Blue Mosque. We were slightly concerned by some of the other posts regarding the construction of the Four Seasons Hotel behind the Zoe, but when we were there in the middle of August the works had stopped however the view from the bedroom window of our suite did ressemble a car park, but how long do you spend looking out of that window when the view from the other side is a wonderful one of the Bosphorus?! The first thing that worried me was the open spiral staircase that leads from the reception up to the courtyard and the rooms beyond, however, if you take your shoes off its much easier to negociate - and a very nice man lugged our incredibly heavy cases up to the suite! The suite itself was at the rear of the hotel, across a small gravelled courtyard and up a small outside staircase to the first floor. It consisted of a lounge area with sofas, a fridge with kettle etc, an amazing bathroom with marble walls, floor and open shower and a lovely bedroom with large comfortable bed and dressing table area. The bathroom had a nice mural on the wall and the bedstead was hand painted with stars and moons. The outside terrace was great for evening drinks watching the sun go down on the river. Breakfast was served in the courtyard and was self service from the bar - it was typically Turkish with fruit, yoghurt, bread, olives, cheese etc. The roof terrace has amazing views to the front of the Bosphorus, and lovely views to the rear of the blue mosque. The staircase to the terrace is very steep and again I found it easier to remove my shoes! The district of Sultanahmet around the hotel is lively and full of restaurants and shops and lovely to walk around in the evening. We ate in two restaurants near the hotel - one was cheaper but wonderful and called Albura ( but watch the owner called Antonio - he follwed me up to the loo and propostioned me 4 days after my wedding!! ) and the other was called Balikci Sabahattin - more expensive and a bit corporate feeling but with very good fish! The other place we ate was 360 Istanbul and it was totally awesome! It is easy to walk from the hotel to most of Istanbul - we walked everywhere - Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Galata Tower, Grand Bazaar etc. Overall we were very pleased with the location and the room in this hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Convenient, Stylish, Fun locale for Visit to istanbul”
Reviews.Author: TallulahB
Reviews.Content: Conveniently located near all the big tourist sites in Istanbul, this boutique hotel is small, comfortable, and unique. We stayed in a double room which included one large bed and one small bed and many windows looking out on the street. The bathroom was very small but unless two people need to be in there at the same time you'll be fine. The hotel has no elevator and a spiral staircase. Be prepared if you get dizzy. The hotel will walk your bags to your room. Breakfast is included and served inside and outside in a lovely garden where you may be visited by the cats who live on the premises. My friend is allergic but the cats are not in the rooms so you shouldn't have a problem. There is also a bar that operates for hotel patrons in the afternoon and evenings and you can take your drinks to the roof to watch the sunset over Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque. It is an excellent added bonus to the space. The front desk was helpful in booking taxis, giving us directions, helping us find the local tram system and making restaurant recommendations. Also answering all of our many questions about Turkish customs and traditions. The area has a number of hotels and restaurants (the Four Seasons is right behind it) and the only harassment you will endure is from carpet salesmen trying to get you to come into their stores. A minor inconvenience. The street noise was minimal but you will hear the call to prayer quite loudly. We thought this was wonderful. There are some larger suites offered at this hotel but I can only speak to the rooms we saw in the main building which were all quite comfortable and decorated with turkish textiles etc...Towels and linens were clean and of a nice quality. Highly recommended Istanbul hotel. There is a discount on the price if you pay in cash.

Reviews.Title: “Great everything.”
Reviews.Author: jfsinmsp
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Cistern Suite, and loved it. I'm planning on stealing the design for the bathroom and using it in my own home someday if I can find a cheap supplier of marble. The location was perfect and near to everything, the staff was very helpful and unusually prompt in responding to emails regarding our reservation. Breakfast was nothing special, but the sitting area was really nice and the courtyard has to be seen to be believed. We visited in March, and it was very cold. Unlike some hotels in the area, the Zoe was heated.

Reviews.Title: “Observations”
Reviews.Author: dirdriller
Reviews.Content: Stayed 10 days in July, 5 in the special double with terrace & 5 in the penthouse - both in the old building. Booking & questions handled very efficiently & both rooms as described. Being hypercritical I would say that the first room would benefit from a new shower curtain, hardly earth shattering but it did give a rather grubby feel to bathroom. The penthouse wasn't quite as I imagined as it & its terrace are below the level of the main roof terrace & very overlooked by it. But I have to say the views from it are superb. No building work problems. Overall a very nice stay.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel, great staff, construction noise affects quality”
Reviews.Author: doodler
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from quite a long stay at the Empress Zoe, booked some time in advance. We were not warned about the construction, despite having been in touch several times with the hotel only days before our arrival. I have no doubt they thought it best not to tell us, so we could not easily make alternate arrangements. Despite this, we had a very enjoyable stay, being early-ish risers. The construction started at 9am daily (10am on Sundays) just outside our window. Fortunately, we had booked a suite, so could move promptly to the living room and lie there if we felt like it. The garden was made largely uninhabitable during the day by the noise (until 7pm), which is a real shame. Most people made sure they had completed breakfast by 9am. The staff were very pleasant to deal with, and very kind to our elderly relative, who had had an accident (not in the hotel) during our stay. I guess I would advise anyone planning a longer stay to check the construction is completed, especially if they are not planning to be out being tourists between 9am and 7pm. No reduction was given for the inconvenience.

Reviews.Title: “Empress Zoe - mixed feelings !”
Reviews.Author: travelpeople_7
Reviews.Content: We arrived at the Empress Zoe on 13th May and were booked to stay for 6 nights. Our room, the Villa Zoe Terrace Suite was extremely pleasant with bedroom, good sitting room, bathroom with walk in shower and very nice terrace with seating. However on raising the bedroom blind we encountered a huge crane only feet from the window in a room that should have had a view of Aya Sofia. The next morning work began at nine am and the noise was dreadful on our terrace and in the room. I am surprised that there has been no mention of this building work in any reviews. It is a huge addition being built to the Four Seasons Hotel immediately behind the Empress Zoe. We checked out of the Empress Zoe on Tuesday 15th May. Had it not been for the construction site adjacent, the location of the hotel is very good as was our room. However it was not a quiet location !

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Empress Zoe hotel”
Reviews.Author: mll
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Empress Zoe in Istanbul May 14 through 17th. The location is perfect, in a quiet location just down the hill from the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Museum and the Haghia Sophia. We found the staff to be friendly and efficient, and a good Turkish breakfast was served every day. The hotel is not for everyone -- especially anyone with a physical problem who would have trouble with uneven surfaces and spiral staircases. There are many steps to climb to get to most of the rooms, but once there our room was charming. This is NOT the Holiday Inn, but more of a Bed and Breakfast hotel. I found that their website is very accurate about describing the rooms and they will answer questions if you ask. [--]. We used the honeymoon room and found it small but very nice, with crisp sheets, fluffy towels, a safe, TV, and a king sized bed. The Turkish bathroom was lovely, and a highlight of our trip. They also will pick you up from the airport, which was fabulous (especially jet lagged at 11:30 in the evening!).

Reviews.Title: “Quirky and delightful”
Reviews.Author: Highgateglobetrotter
Reviews.Content: Despite being unable to obtain one of the coveted garden rooms - we booked five months in advance - we loved our stay here and would come again. Avoid room 23 if you can as it overlooks the junction on which the hotel is situated and has a cupboard of a bathroom, but if you have no other choice double glazing shuts out most noise at night and the fan from the air-conditioning (not yet switched on in early May) kept us reasonably cool too. The garden at the back is truly delightful and there can be no better start to the day than bringing your choice from the small but well put together buffet selection to one of the small tables amongst mature plants, flowers and ancient walls. The roof terrace is also charming and has wonderful views of the Blue Mosque, Agha Sophia AND the Marmaris Sea. There is no lift and stairs everywhere so this hotel is not for those who find these things difficult, but it is for anyone who loathes the blandness of most hotels and is happy to be without TV during their stay. Staff were extremely friendly and helpful. We were particularly pleased to be directed to the Heritage school and shop where it is possible to buy kelims that help to support a nomadic tribe elsewhere in Turkey - beautiful designs at much lower prices than tourist outlets.

Reviews.Title: “Choose your room carefully”
Reviews.Author: CornwallBracken
Reviews.Content: I booked Empress Zoe because of the reviews, here and in other guides. I have to admit to being a bit disappointed - for me, it didn't live up to the hype. Yes, the location is great for the main sites, but many - even most - Sultanhamet hotels are similarly close. The hotel is situated on a very touristy street which means there are bars and restaurants close by, but that comes with the hassle from tourist restaurant touts. Easily enough dealt with, but it can become wearing! Our room faced the street and at night it was noisy, despite being early in the season: in the summer I can imagine that the noise from the lively hostel almost opposite would be intrusive. In addition to the street noise, people coming into the hotel late, loud plumbing and the people next door talking could be clearly heard. I didn't expect to need earplugs. To be fair, the hotel made it very clear to me that the room overlooked the street, and I can imagine that the rooms overlooking the garden would be more peaceful. On the plus side, the room was very clean and the decor was interesting and unusual: the size was okay. The bathroom was very small, but it was a good shower and the toiletries provided can't be beat! I found the reception and cleaning staff efficient, helpful and friendly. The same could not be said for the barman who was surly, and often simply not to be found during opening hours. Breakfast was excellent. The garden is beautiful, and a major attraction, especially in the warmer weather, with the cats adding a homely touch! The views from the roof terrace were spectacular. So - choose your room carefully. By the way, the airport pick up is expensive: I opted for it to save the hassle of arriving in a new place and potentially arguing with taxi drivers but many hotels provide the service free or there are lots of companys in Istanbul who will do the same thing for a fraction of the price.

Reviews.Title: “Fab location and friendly staff”
Reviews.Author: VoyageLondon
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Empress Zoe having read some good reviews. The location is excellent - 5 mins to Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace, yet hotel is situtated on a quiet street. The rooms are clean and comfortable (not masive - but then we only slept in our room - spending all our time out seeing the sights). All the staff were very friendly and happy to help with any questions/queries. The garden is pretty (it was a bit to cold to make full use of it) and the hotel cats (Mojo, Woby and Jasper) are all very friendly. I would stay that for the price and location you would be hard pushed to find a better hotel in Istanbul. To access the rooms you have to go up a steep spiral staircase (as mentioned on their website) and so would be unsuitable for disabled/elderly/very young children.

Reviews.Title: “Lived up to the high expectations!”
Reviews.Author: mn4tcl
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel based on the very strong recommendation in the Time Out Istanbul City Guide (and it is also a featured hotel in the Lonely Planet too) and so was expecting great things! The hotel did not disappoint. We had room 42 which the is a double room with private terrace overlooking the sea. The room would be quite small if we hadnt have had the terrace to use. The room was 60+ steps up so you need to be nimble, but the staff were more than helpful and carried our bags up & down without asking. The choice of room is important as I guess it could be noisy if you were staying on the ground floor (see other reviews). The location of this hotel is 2nd to none... 5mins walk to the Blue Mosque, Ayaya Sofya and the Topkapi Palace, yet you are away from the crowds. Yes, there are carpet sellers and very keen restaurant/cafe owners who ask you if you'd like to buy something from their shop every time you pass by, but this is Turkey!! If you land at the Sabiha Gokcen airport (on the Asia side) you'd do well to accept the 40Euro taxi to the hotel that The Empress Zoe offers - the public transport options are very limited indeed. I would recommend this hotel to my friends and family.

Reviews.Title: “Empress Zoe Hotel - chic, cute, charming, convenient, cheap”
Reviews.Author: anilegna
Reviews.Content: stayed in the smallest and cheapest room (75 euros) they had so cannot say that I was too surprised that the room was tiny, while my room was small, it had a great view and while it was a bit on the dusty side, I liked everything else about the hotel, the location (right around the corner from the much more expensive 4 seasons-- & honestly after trying the 40 euros breakfast at the 4 season [just to really hang out & see the former prison] I can tell you the Empress Zoe breakfast tasted much better- and was free) was very convenient (esp. to the Topkapi Palace and Haghia Sofia) ... was at 1st worried about being harassed by aggressive touts in the hood but actually had a very pleasant 2 nights stay here (either the touts were also on holiday or they are just not that aggressive) the hotel was very tastefully decorate & renovated (used to be a hamman) the staff from the man that cleaned the rooms to the guys/gals behind the reception to the boy learning his Espanol behind the bar -- all were all friendly and professional I do hope to visit Turkey again and will come back to this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful experience”
Reviews.Author: dollardave
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful stay at the Empress Zoe and would highly recommend the hotel. My wife, friend, and I stayed in room 603 (duplex) with views (from the top floor; there are two floors in the suite) of the aghia sophia on one side, and the sea on the other. The room was fabulous; we enjoyed a few happy hours while like at the sea. Unlike a previous review (dated march 23 on this website), we found the service to be OUTSTANDING. The front desk was very helpful in recommmending restaurants and sites, and one night, even walked us to a very nice local restaurant in the neighborhood. From the front desk, to the bar-tender, to people who worked during the breakfast, we had nothing but wonderful, friendly service. The location of the hotel cannot be beat.
